item.title: Google Chrome to remove detailed cookie and site data controls
item.description: A month ago I ran into an obscure Google Chrome bug on macOS that caused the "All cookies and site data" page in Chrome settings (chrome://settings/siteData) to load very slowly. You can see this page if you open Preferences, select "Privacy and security", "Cookies and other site data", and then "See all cookies and site data". I filed a bug report with Chromium's issue tracker. Since then, some members of the Chromium team have been trying to track down the cause of the bug, a normal and boring process. However, this week I got an update on the issue that was shocking to me:

item.title: Rejected internal applicants twice as likely to quit | Cornell Chronicle
item.description: Internal job applicants who face rejection are nearly twice as likely to leave their organizations than those who were either hired for an internal job or had not applied for a new job at all, ILR School research finds.

item.title: Noteflakes: How I Write Code: Pen & Paper
item.description: I am a self taught programmer. I first started programming as a kid, and have never bothered to formally study this discipline. To me, programming is first of all a pleasant creative pursuit. It’s a bit like putting together and taking apart all kinds of machines, except these machines happen to be virtual constructions, and you get to keep your hands clean (well, mostly…) Incidentally, this pleasant activity is also how I support my family.
item.author: (by Sharon Rosner)

item.title: BPFTrace & Julia: An introduction to UProbes
item.description: BPFTrace is an observability tool inspired by DTrace for Linux. It uses the eBPF infrastructure in the Linux kernel to implemented lightweight tracing of the kernel and applications. This note is written from a Linux perspective, but much of this should hold on systems with DTrace.
